Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women

Promoting Renewable Energy in Mae Hong Son Province
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - power generation
Project Objective To overcome barriers to the provision of Renewable Energy RE services in integrated provincial renewable energy programmes in Thailand
Increase of power generation capacity and usage from RE systems in MHS

comment.narrative: RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 17 MW on grid and 24 MW offgrid
By the end of the project RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 2706 MW on grid and more than 24 MW offgrid This is equivalent to an increase of at least 55000 MWhyear
RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29220 MW on grid and 255 kW offgrid June 2015

description.narrative: Models for RE generation application which can be replicated in other areas demonstrated

comment.narrative: No new models for RE generation application
At least 3 new models for RE generation application developed and operational Models ready to be replicated in other areas hydro solar and biodigesters

Several models related to RE generation application service delivery fund management and sustainable utilization of RE were sketched out but not finalized For instance policy support for RE applications energy access in forest reserved area facilitation to local government in RE technologies operation maintenance OM community management for productive uses of RE technologies women empowerment in ICS realization and promotion RE revolving fund Clean Energy Fund for income generation and livelihoods improvement for the marginalized groups

description.narrative: Outcome 1 Strengthened institutional organizational and social capacity results in planning management and implementation of integrated RE programmes in MHS Chiang Rai Chiang Mai and Tak
No of RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

comment.narrative: None
At least 2 RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

3 RE microhydro power projects were proposed and developed by 3 local governments Tambon Administrative Organizations or TAOs in line with local and provincial plans TAOs will be the owner of the plants Completed

description.narrative: No of working RE management models established

comment.narrative: None
At least 3 management models established offgrid hydro biodigesters solar

A management structure for off grid microhydro power was established The agreed structure includes responsibilities of provincial and local concerned agencies and was agreed with the participation of local communities

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Financially sustainable RE systems operational in MHS Chiang Mai Chiang Rai and Tak

No of ongrid solar farm projects approved installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016

description.narrative: Outcome 3 Technical support is available locally for the development management and maintenance of RE applications in MHS Chiang Rai Chiang Mai and Tak
An improved design of an ICS suitable for situation in MHS

comment.narrative: No knowledge centre or experts easily available
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized and being used among 55 project volunteers Completed

Documented and published experienceslessons learned from all technologies implemented by end of 2016

By end of 2016 all lessons learned documented and published
Centre of learning approved and operational by end of 2016
At least 2 guidelines for replication published eg a on management models for offgrid applications b incentive schemesfinancial model for RE
At least 2 important lessons learned included in policy making at central level

0
0
One guideline for local technicians on technical field assessments to determine potential for offgrid microhydro power was published and 700 copies disseminated to provincial and local concerned agencies and TAOs in MHS
Information on several topics and themes of important lessons learned ie on microhydro power policy financial support mechanisms appropriate service delivery models for accessible and affordable RE technologies in poverty stricken areas for offgrid marginalized groups have been gathered This information will be used in coming year to determine key learnings for inclusion in policies at central level

title.narrative: FS Catalyzing Sustainability of THs PA System

description.narrative: PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System

title.narrative: Terminal Review: Catalyzing the Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System (CATSPA) PIMS 3825

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation at Tarutao National Park

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To overcome barriers to effective management and sustained financing of Thailands protected area system

1 Policy guidelines and rules enable successful implementation of effective management plans designing new revenue mechanisms and improving comanagement efforts particularly with communities and local government

comment.narrative: Regulations and policies exist but are not clear enough or enforced properly Gaps in specific regulations may be hindering PA achievement
New policy guidelines and or new policies in place to facilitate PA management planning budgets finance and comanagement

1 Recommendations on the PA system plan and the policy brief on innovation to make Thailands protected areas more valuable have been finalized A highlevel consultation platform will be organized by Q32015
2 The 5year integration plan has been completed the national park management master plan has been revised by updating some information related to marine national parks emerging MPA reform issue
3 The report on preparation of a National Protected Area System Plan sourcebook is being translated prior to use in various settings for discussion on the following issues proposed PA categories and zones within PAs PA governance relations with local and resident communities including integration with surrounding land use the various policies that may need modification to fit within DNP practices the numerous potential funding mechanisms with a view to selecting those that are most likely succeed how to generate the many benefits to protected areas and how to build broader support from multiple stakeholders and how to build the institutional and staff capacities to implement the improved management of Thailands PAs

description.narrative: 2 Formal DNP management and financial effectiveness capacity programs in place

comment.narrative: Limited formal capacity programs or materials
Specific programs and materials in place

The trainings and capacity building workshops organised under the project remains piecemeal and has not been systematically integrated into the DNP system yet The trainings capacity buildings have been designed around the key themes of CATSPA including sustainable financing financial scorecards Management Effectiveness for PA tools and approaches the economics of biodiversity and ecosystem conservation communication for conservation as well as SMART patrolling The two core curricular drafted last year have not yet been rolling out due to the lack of engagement with the core groups of the Effectiveness Unit and the Training Division of DNP The rapid assessment on training need assessment has been done and it will inform the development of Marine Protected Areas Capacity Building module to support DNPs in the reform of the marine protected area management The consultations with the Training Division The Recreation Division as well as the superintendents of the marine protected areas have been undertaken twice and the outline of the module has been developed

description.narrative: 3 Completed objectivedriven PA management plans and budgets provide clarity on financial need gap

comment.narrative: Less than 50 of PAs have management plans Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms
100 of project demonstration PAs and a growing number of PAs system wide have management plans and budgets target is 65 by end of project

80 of project demonstration sites have management plans
Management Plans are under development for Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP The latter will be integrated into the Thung YaiHuai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage Site for UNESCO submission
As noted previously management plans are in place for Doi Inthanon NP Eastern Forest Complex Tarutao embedded in the Andaman Sea Management Plan and Huay Kha Kheng WS

description.narrative: 4 Improvements in DNP budget allocations and increased nongovernment PA revenues and sources reduce financial gaps

comment.narrative: Approximately 75 of nonsalary PA system financing is government budget and 25 is tourism No other significant sources exist
Additional revenue sources contribute an additional 10 to 5 project PA demonstration sites and PA system plans in place to target a 10 increase across system

There is no increase in the PA revenues yet However the Doi Inthanon Conservation Trust Fund has been launched with strong partnership with the private sector and looks set to that the park will gain additional source of funding supporting their management Further revenue schemes have been studied with recommendations provided by a consultant for the potential for launching a scheme for a special car license plate with the Depart of Land Transport to support Thai PAs and for proposals to enhance funding for MPAs through the introduction of the conservation car plates

description.narrative: 5 Comanagement approaches mainstreamed and effective

comment.narrative:
Comanagement approaches between PA such as Complex and with communities and other stakeholders PAC are relatively new poorly understood and underutilized
UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score 34

Complex management plan and budget analysis reveals value of Complex approach PACs are fully functioning and contributing to management in 5 project demonstration PAs
UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score 55

A final draft of Eastern forest Complex management plan was developed and is being adapted through a newly established EFCom Protected Areas Advisory Committee PACsThe positive experience with the creation of the Doi Inthanon National Park Business Plan is also being studied for application at EFCOM and Tarutao
PACs in the demonstration sites are all functional and contributing to management
The 2014 UNDP Financial Scorecard score is 3136 The baseline UNDP financial scorecard score was 3390

description.narrative: Improved governance supports enabling environment for long term PA system sustainability
11 5year integrated national PA system management plan and financial strategy endorsed

comment.narrative: Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms Formal bottomup financing strategies do not exist

A financial gap analysis reveals true financial needs or gaps for the 5 project pilot PAs and the PA system The System and 5 PAs have financing strategies Approach is being rolled out to full PA system

The final 5years National Parks Management Plan was refined and updated in particular relating to marine national parks
The financial gap and needs assessment has not yet been completed for the PA system Nevertheless the business plan for Doi Inthanon NP has been under development but faces difficulty on getting actual expenditure of each government agency in relate to key conservation activities they provided for the park annually

description.narrative: 12 Policies strengthening role of PA Advisory Committees and community participation in PA management is in place

comment.narrative: Limited guidance or training material exists to promote collaboration with Local government or PA committees
Policy is strengthened and guidance materials exist

No result on policies being strengthened nor guidance materials in place yet The project has reached the level that it managed to form the Eastern Forest Complex 8 PAs Protected Areas Advisory Committee PAC with 34 members consisting of the Foundation to Protect the Forests in the 5 Eastern Province under the royal patronage the deputychairman of Chantaburi Provinces Chamber of Commerce the Mayor of Rayong the Chief Executive of the Chantaburi Provincial Administrative Organization the East Water Company the Mab Ta put Industrial estate Regional Water Authority head of subdistricts etc The facilitation the coordination and the mechanism to run the EFCOM PAC forms the foundation of the policy recommendations and guidance materials towards the development of complexlevel PAC

description.narrative: 13 Effective ME and knowledgebased data management system is in place to assess progress and to inform policy decisions

comment.narrative: Actual management and cost performance is not tracked No formal ME system looking at total effectiveness of performance exists Adaptive management is not utilized
DNP has ME program utilizing METT and UNDP Scorecard or similar and is evaluating PAs starting with 5 project PAs Adaptive management measures and processes are in place

The 2014 METT assessment in the 5 demonstration sites has been taken in September 2014
Later on the METT is replicated for Krang Kra Chan Complex the proposing World Heritage Site to assess management effectiveness

description.narrative: Institutional and individual capacities enhanced
21 Effectiveness Unit in place to support project and institutionalized for longterm role in DNP

comment.narrative: No such integration body within DNP supporting complex management approach

An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP eg being able to generate nonbudgetary revenue complex management approach and PA comanagement effectively demonstrated

The Effective Unit or Institution of Innovation Protected Areas and National Parks is in place And the new Marine National Parks Section establishment will be a potential unit for CATSPA capacity building including for competence in developing additional financing and implementing effective management However the EFComs project implementation such as SMART Program and EFcoms PAC will be showcase for complex management regarding internal practice and external support

description.narrative: 22 Capacity Building Programs on Effective PA Management and Financial Planning Developed for DNP staff as well as partners and Institutionalised within DNP and partners

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists
Training materials and curriculum developed Training completed for key management at pilot PA sites
Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning Training materials and curriculum have been developed for system and site levels

description.narrative: 23 Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning developed and institutionalized within DNP and implemented at 5 PA demonstration sites

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists

Training materials and curriculum developed Training completed for key management and 5 demonstration PA sites An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP UNDP Capacity scorecard performance increases 25 over baseline year

A series of training activities have been developed on METT with 200 participants sustainable financing with 80 participants business plans with 70 participants communication for conservation with 80 participants and SMART patrolling with 250 participants completed

description.narrative: New models of PA management support effective management of the System
41 Communication Strategy and Materials developed for partnership engagement and advocacy

comment.narrative: Communication is not well integrated in PA system management
Communication is strategically planned integrated in PA managemen and effectively support partnership engagement and advocacy

Activities conducted under CATSPA have been shared on social media and CATSPA blog in Thai and Facebook Key issues advocated by CATSPA eg SMART Patrol Territorial and Marine Conservation Trust Funds have been disseminated through social media
A major publication Parks for LifeWhy We Love our National Parks has been prepared stressing the values and importance of Thai protected areas in an attractive and easily accessible format for a wide general public readership

description.narrative: 42 Lessonslearned Captured into Mangement Models for Replication and Policy Decision

comment.narrative: No systematic management of knowledge policy decision is mostly not linked to studyresearch or lessonlearned
Various forms of lessonlearned technical study is easily accessible policy decision correlates with available knowledge
The knowledge management including best practices and lesson learned has been planned to collect and synthesis systematically by a contracted communication consultant

description.narrative: Revenue generation mechanisms and management approaches are assessed and tested at 5 PA demonstration sites leading to increased funding levels of the PA system
31 New PA Integrated Management Planning Framework including tools and methods in place and implemented at the pilot units Outputs 21 22 in Prodoc

comment.narrative: Basic management plan templates exist Most plans contain few specific requirements actions against clear objectives

Each of the 5 project PA sites and 1 Eastern Forest Complex has complete functional management plans Site level activity plans developed and implemented in line with METT baseline result and management plan A Clear and consistent PA management framework exists for the PA system METT score increased by 10 at midterm by 20 at the end
Capacity building including sustainable financing leads to more effective PA management METT scores increased by 20 over baseline for each of 5 demonstration PAs

Management Plans for Doi inthanon NP Tarutao NP combined with the Andaman Sea Management Plan Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary combined with Thung YaiHuai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage management plan have been completed and are being implementing in the sites The Eastern Forest Complex management plan has been completed and will soon be used for EFCom PACs supporting plan and a business plan Only at 2 project PA sites the Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP are management plans yet to be completed
The result of 2014 METT score are in this following
HKK 200963201473 10
KL20095920148324
DI 2009772014743
KCKW 20095320146613
TRT 20095920146910

description.narrative: 32 Financing Mechanism Identified and Implemented at the pilot units

comment.narrative:
No feasibility or valuation studies in place Sustainable financing mechanisms largely absent from PA system Environmentally economic tools are not systematically applied
Conservation Funds have been looked at in a limited way

Sustainable financing mechanisms assessed and being pursued within at least 3 PA sites as appropriate Community local government and other stakeholders partnerships leads to better management of well designed and managed funds setup sourcing funding from variety of sources including PA income Financial Scorecard score increased to 55 at the end of the project

A Conservation Trust Fund was created for Doi Inthanon National Park with the aim to draw private sector and CSOs supports to PA management For Doi Inthanon a Conservation Trust Fund Committee is chaired by the Chairman of the Hotel Association in Chiang Mai Province wherein Doi Inthanon NP is situated with the participation from local CSOs and academics Moreover the first business plan for PA management has been introduced and developing at this pilot site based on 10 selected prioritized activities from the Doi Inthanon National Park Management Plan following a participatory process In Tarutao the stakeholders consultations to form the Tarutao Conservation Trust Fund based on the diving fee and other tourismrelated revenue have been conducted For EFCOM the financial mechanism will be PES from the Industrial Estate to support the watershed conservation and management of the complex The valuation of water ecosystem services of EFCOM is being conducted and the engagement with the key private sector in the areas is being developed through the PAC platform There is no financial mechanism designed for the subWEFCOM pilot
The Financial Scorecard was assessed in system level The site levels and forest complex were tested by the same scorecard as experimentation in September 2014 The 2014 system levels financial score is 2956 which decreased from 2012 with gained score at 3390 However this decrease can be explained by a misapplication of the scorecard in the baseline exercise and in fact it was acknowledged that the there was a marked improvement since 2012

description.narrative: 33 Co management Approaches Enhanced including strengthened PAC at sitelevel and mechanism channels for public engagement in PA management established at site level Outputs 4142 in Prodoc

comment.narrative: PACs are underutilized and communities and local governments are not engaged in PA management in a consistent or effective manner
PA system PACs in particular are utilized more effectively at pilot PA sites METT score increased by 10 at midterm by 20 at the end of the project

The Eastern Forest Complexs PAC was recently established by the CATSPA project in close collaboration with Regional Conservation Office No2 Sriracha which has responsibility for 8 protected areas in Eastern Forest Complex In the meantime at the western forest complex and in particular at HKK Klong Lan and Mae Wong work is progressing on buffer zone management involving PAC members in order to reduce impacts from encroachment or nontimber product collection Moreover CATSPA will organize 4 regions PACs lesson learned workshops

description.narrative: 34 Regional DNP Offices and PA Staff Capacities Enhanced to Coordinate Management Support and budget allocations across multiple PA in Eastern Complex for improved biodiversity conservation management effectiveness and cost efficiencies Output 43 in Prodoc

comment.narrative: Complex plan and budget strategy allows comparison with PA level approach and optimizes management of individual PAs involved

Promotion of Regional complex management system leads to better management of PAs in Eastern Forest Complex measured by METT scores of 8 demonstration PA sites within EFCOM METT score increased by 10 at midterm by 20 at the end of the project

Better management of Eastern Forest Complex was introduced by approaching Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool SMART Patrol for the whole complex and the Corridor management between Khao Ang Rue Nai Wildlife Sanctuary and Khao Cha Mao National Park EFComs SMART Patrol is initiative approach as the complex patrolling system as well as corridor management

description.narrative: Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)

title.narrative: PIMS 4033 THA Community based forest mgt FSP DOA 15Feb2012
Mid-Term Review on Inegrated Community-Based Forest and Catchment Management through an Ecosystem Service Approach

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Expanded CBFCM coverage through pilot testing and upscaling of best practice using PES and biocarbon financing schemes and mechanisms
21 Number and Type of PES and biocarbon financing schemes developed and applied in place for CBFCM in the 4 pilot sites

comment.narrative: Currently there are no PES and biocarbon financing strategies and schemes developed andor applied for CBFCM within the 4 REO pilot site regions
At least 4 PES and biocarbon financing schemes 1 for each REO region pilot site are developed and implemented during the project cycle

There are no PES scheme implemented yet in the 4 pilot sites Each has established the scope and the scale of PES design and the ecosystem services to be focused confirmed the baseline information on biocarbon biodiversity indicators and socioeconomic data developing community PES action plans to be matched with the private sector support Some of the activities in the community PES action plans have been tested run with the cofinancing support from the CSR scheme from the Siam Cement Group Engagement with key buyers are already developed and strengthened notably in Mae Sa and Tha Chin The economic valuation for each pilot site is underway and will be completed in October 2015 The pilot sites expect to fully operationalize the PES scheme by January 2016

description.narrative: 22 Total area of cactchment forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins that benefiting from PES and biocarbon financing schemes

comment.narrative:
Current accumulative total of all forest under community management in each of the 4 catchment basin pilot sites
Data collection on total coverage of community managed forests within each catchment basin will need to be undertaken at the start of the project
Collectively 15000 hectares are identified and designated CBFCM forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins

As the PES scheme in each of the pilot site has not been operationalized the benefit is still at 0 hectare
However the project has established the clear scope of where to assess and monitor the biocarbon benefit as well as started conducting preparation activities to prepare communities to participate in the PES scheme including the fire break line the check dams and reforestation with monitoring process

description.narrative: 23 Ton of CO2 sequestered and or avoided emissions within the framework of implemented PES schemes accumulative of all 4 pilot project area catchment basin sites

comment.narrative: Some work on assessment of forest carbon has been initiated by the RFD and DWNP for Thailands RPIN application of the World Banks Forest Carbon Partnership Facility FCPF Readiness Plan as well as by independent studies by specialists in various universities Forest carbon stock assessment will have to be undertaken for the 4 pilot sites
Existence of knowledge and data base of forest in term of tons of carbon dioxide equivalent sequestration

RECOFTC trained students and communities to use common methodology for carbon absorption measurement in all pilot sites Biocarbon measurement in the second year has been measured in early 2015 using participatory monitoring process trained by RECOFT with engagement from communities and local governments in each area

description.narrative: 24 Keystone species population maintained or enhanced at the 4 pilot sites by reducing threats

comment.narrative: Threats to forests and associated biodiversity continues at demonstration sites
Existence on the keystone speciess threats reduction measures

REOs and RECOFTC made a survey and list of indicator species in Q22015 Each site will conduct a workshop with communities to identify species by the end of July 2015 as well as will collect baseline data in September 2015 in Q32015

description.narrative: 25 5 Increase in livelihood quality Index income health debt and life security of households from the baseline

comment.narrative:
Some socioeconomic data can be obtained by the Community Development Department and the Department of Agricultural Extensions
For the 4 selected pilot sites data collection must be designed specifically for the purpose of measuring livelihood changes resulting from the project
5 increase in livelihood quality of life index in the projects participating communities

The average income of Mae Sa watershed Tha Chin watershed and Lam Sebai watershed were collected in 2014 The other aspects of livelihood index health debt and life security has not been finalized yet Average income in Mae Sa is 60000 120000 Bahthousehold Year and debt was 40 Income average of Tha Chin is between 10000 50000 Bahthousehold Year Income average of Lam Sebai is between 5000 10000 BahthouseholdYear For Pha Ngan as the scoping of ecosystem services has changed from the planned scheme in 2014 due to the lack of receptiveness and participation of the local government in the originally selected areas the socioeconomic data needs to be reworked The data collection has started in June 2015 and is being finalised in September 2015

description.narrative: 26 Capacities of local authorities and community land users in land use options that enhance PES and to ensure marketbased payments from PES and biocarbon financing for improved livelihoods Environmental Quality of key ES parameters such as water quality soil nutrient levels sedimentation

comment.narrative:
Local capacities in sustainable land use options must be assessed at the beginning of project
There has been some training provided to local authorities and community land user community forest watershed networks on sustainable land use practices through various government and independent projects ES and PES biocarbon financing

At least 4 Tambon Administrative Organisations TAOs are actively engaged in PES biocarbon scheme implementation within their respective communities in support of CBFCM
Overall land use practices in the four pilot catchment basins sufficiently improve

6 TAOs 1 in Mae Sa 1 in Lam Sebai 1 in Koh Phangan and 3 in Tha Chin in four pilot watersheds are involved in the trainings capacity building process organised by the projects including the handson training in biocarbon assessment and monitoring community action plan development and key indicator species In Mae Sa although the PES preparation activities are focused in the area under the responsible of 1 TAO the other 4 TAOs which are in the same catchment have also been engaged to learn about PES and in the capacity building process In Mae Sa and Tha Chin the TAOs have been collaborating closely in the development of the community PES action plans which have the potential to be integrated into the local development plans The engagement of TAO in Lam Sebai has been improved due to improved coordination from the project team and the field coordinator at site level For Pha Ngan with the change of the focused area the collaboration with TAO has been improved

description.narrative: 27 Number of national and regional level forums meetings and documents highlighting best practice and lessons learned in using PES and biocarbon financing for CBFCM

comment.narrative:
Currently PES knowledge is in limited only in acdemic society and has no communication process intoi watershed and communities levels
PES study is limited and unclear formulation under Thailand context

At least 4 regional best practice lesson learned exchange forum on PES
At least 1 National forum for PES policy strategies and collaboration declaration of cooperation

Project Office Environment Policy and Institute Advisor and Environmental Economic Advisor conducted best practices lesson learned exchange forum on PES on 22 July 2015 Speakers from Department of National Parks Wildlife and plant Conservation DNP respond for CATSPA project GIZ respond for ECOBEST project USAID respond for LEAF Thailand project and four REOs respond for CBFCM project in four pilot watersheds were invited to share their experience from implementation of PES schemes in local level including start up of project implementation result lesson learned guideline expansion to practices as well as suggestion for implementation REOs can apply lesson learned from different project to implement their CBFCM project

description.narrative: Strengthened policy environment and systemic capacities to promote sustainable communitybased forest and catchment management through PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms
11 Number of national policies and plans identified that incorporate PES and biocarbon financing mechanism in support of CBFCM

comment.narrative:
Forestry and catchment management policies and legal instruments currently have limited inclusion of CBFCM
National Regional and Provincial Plans do not include provisions for CBFCM or PES biocarbon financing

Natural Resources and Environmental Policies and Plans adapt in implementation of CBFCM utilizing PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms as a mechanism for catchment and forest conservation and management

Key policy and legal frameworks related to PES schemes and biocarbon were reviewed and recommendations drafted on the priority entry points including the Environmental Quality Promotion Action Plan 20172021 The draft is being reviewed by the project technical advisory team and will be put for a wider public consultation in the next policy dialogue scheduled in November 2015
The first policy dialogue with key agencies working on PES and biocarbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment MONRE was organised and chaired by the Deputy Director General of the Pollution Control Department There were representatives from the Department of Marine and Coastal Resource DMCR Department of Water Resources DWR Royal Forest Department RFD Department of National Parks Wildlife and Plant Conservation DNP Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning ONEP Office of the Permanent Secretary OPS and Biodiversity Based Economy Development Office BEDO The representatives shared the constraints and opportunities they see in piloting the Payment for Ecosystem Services in their different context The meeting came to a resolution that there needs to be concrete recommendations on the practical implementation of PES in Thailand in three key aspects 1 enabling policy and legal frameworks especially with regards to the establishment of a PES trust fund in each locality to be an operating mechanism 2 engagement with communities to prepare their capacities and readiness 3 policy incentives for the private sector to support PES schemes

description.narrative: 12 Existence of a multiagencymulti sectoral mechanism for CBFCMPES Biocarbon dialogue consultation with inclusive participation from all relevant government organizations CSOa academia private sector and CBFCM community networks

comment.narrative:
Seperated and disorganized data base with limited access
Lack of key agency under MONRE or government agency taking clearly responsibility control and monitoring in this regards
Adhoc Working Group established under the National Environmental Board on Economic Instrument for forest and catchment management

Adhoc working Group has not established under the National Environment Board on Economic Instrument for Forest and Catchment Management yet However an informal network of exchanges among seven agencies working on PES and biocarbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment MONRE consisting of the 7 key agencies participating in the policy dialogue as mentioned above In the first policy dialogue organised in June 2015 the meeting came up with two options in forming this Adhoc working Group 1 the working group could be part of the newlyestablished Subcommittee on the Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity TEEB coordinated by the Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning ONEP and reporting to the National Biodiversity Committee and the National Environment Board 2 the working group could be under the Bureau of Natural Resources and Environmental Strategy under the Office of the Permanent Secretary of MONRE The technical consultant on policy framework is now reviewing the pros and cons of the two options and will present them for consideration in the next policy dialogue

description.narrative: 13 Institutional capacities strengthened at national ME office and regional levels 4 pilot REO training centres to implement PES and biocarbon financing schemed in support of CBFCM

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge and understanding in PES and Biocarbon mechanism and measures
At least 4 REOs can develop mechanisms in applying PES into pratical CBFCM and natural resource management

4 Pilot REOs and the national project management unit have accumulated more handson capacities building as part of the process in developing the PES scheme in each locality
Key capacities strengthened through the learning by doing process included
1 Biocarbon assessment and monitoring
2 Survey and monitoring process for key indicator species
3 Engagement with communities in developing the community PES action plans as well as capacity buildings for communities to conduct local monitoring of biocarbon and biodiversity resources in the areas
4 Economic valuation for the key ecosystem services in the pilot areas as part of the consultants works on economic valuation started in April October 2015
At midterm point of the project it can be said that the 4 pilot REOs have acquired theoretical understanding as well as handson experiences in developing PES schemes even though the degree of understanding varies from one REO to the other The pilot REOs as well as the project management unit have also been more exposed to exchanges of experiences with other projects in the country notably the GIZsupported ECOBEST aiming at operationalising TEEB and the USAIDLEAF aiming at exploring the Low Emission Actions in the Forest Sector and outside the country The Project Manager attended The Regional Workshop on Payment for Environment Services held from 2425 November 2014 in Hanoi City Vietnam in order to exchange of experience on the application of PES schemes and foster collaboration and partnership among stakeholder in the Greater Mekong Region

description.narrative: 14 Existence of an active national CBFCM data base that includes relevant information such as natural resource consumptions ratespatterns biodiversity levels PES biocarbon data generated through baseline studies and participatory M E and identification of best practice

comment.narrative: Currently no such database exist in Thailand
Creation of a National CBFCM PESbiocarbon financing database and mechanisms for information dissemination and knowledge sharing

The meeting with the seven agencies including DMCR DWR RFD ONEP OPS and BEDO was conducted on 9 June 2015 in order to discuss about the issues of national CBFCM database The workshop with the same seven agencies GIZ and USAID will be conducted on 22 July 2015 Lesson learned and best practice from project which responded by these agencies such as CATSPA of DNP ECOBEST of GIZ LEAF of USAID and CBFCM will be shared and discussed We will use the information and knowledge sharing form the workshop to create a national CBFCM PES database The meeting and workshop of seven agencies GIZ and other related agencies will be conducted continuously in Q 42015 and Q 12016 in order to formulate national CBFCM database

title.narrative: Strengthening Thailand’s Capacity to Link Climate Policy

description.narrative: Strengthening Thailand’s Capacity to Link Climate Policy and Public Finance

title.narrative: Project Document- Strengthening Thailand's Capacity to Link Climate Policy and Public Finance
Strengthening Thailand?s Capacity to Link Climate Policy
Strengthening Thailand?s Capacity to Link Climate Policy

description.narrative: Strengthening Thailand’s Capacity to link Climate Policy and Public Finance
independent political entity

(1) Availability of technical tools developed to mainstream Climate Change into sectoral development planning and budgeting (2) Number of budget requests from sectoral agencies incorporating climate change analysis formulated and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Availability of the common framework for Climate Change analysis at the project and programme level to be integrated as criteria for the Bureau of Budget’s consideration for budget appropriation (4) Availability of options for inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangements for climate finance

comment.narrative: (1) 0 (2) 0 (3) Climate Public Expenditures and Institutional Review (CPEIR) completed in 2012 but recommendations not yet developed into a common framework for budget requests and appropriation (4) No inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement mechanism for climate finance

(1) Cost-effectiveness assessment for mitigation actions developed and tested with the Energy Conservation Fund projects to provide guideline in climate change analysis for mitigation actions under Ministry of Energy (2) 2 budget requests incorporating climate change benefit analysis formulated by two key departments under Ministry of Agriculture and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed and discussed among sectoral, policy and planning, and budget agencies (4) Recommendation on inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement for climate finance in Thailand endorsed by the National Climate Change Committee

(1) Cost-effectiveness assessment for mitigation actions developed and tested with two energy-related projects under the Energy Conservation Fund (2) 2 budget requests incorporating climate change benefit analysis formulated by Royal Irrigation Department and Land Development Department under Ministry of Agriculture and cooperatives (3) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed and published

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis as a tool for climate change planning and budgeting widely communicated to related government agencies for policy advocacy (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee for views and comments (3) Training Module based on the Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed (4) Communication materials related to climate change benefit analysis works undertaken during 2013-15 developed and shared with general public

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis widely communicated to related government agencies through workshops, high level policy forum, social media, and website (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee in July and further actions on modification and revision were recommended (3) Training Module to be finalized in January 2017 (4) Communication materials i.e. policy briefs, info-graphic, animation etc. developed and shared with general public

description.narrative: Vulnerable groups in Thailand increasingly legally empowered and protected.

STEPII is to foster a resilient society in the southern provinces to expand participatory planning and sustainable livelihood,integrate knowledge,best practices and lessons learned,in the evolving southern context,and filling identified development gaps.
Other General Services - support to civil society

1) Number of common space for peace platform in place to raise civic awareness 2) Number of pilot alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanism models developed 3) Number of vulnerable groups/communities benefiting from small grants projects

comment.narrative: 1) Lack of awareness and common strategic roles/position in peace process and participation of CSO, peace network and local people. 2) Zero alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanisms in place for effective legal services and quality legal protection 3) Zero small grant projects supported for resilience regarding participation, employment and livelihood.
1) 3 peace platforms organised for target groups 2) Alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanisms in place in Pattani 3) At least 5 small grants projects implemented and administered

Advancing Anti-corruption Efforts in Thailand - A Multifaceted Approach (AAA) Project.

This project combines a number of initiatives, including mitigating corruption risks in public procurement; youth empowerment and integrity education; and social entrepreneurship and social innovations in the fight against corruption.
Anti corruption

Indicators for Output 1 1.1 Number of legal and operational guidance documents for the new Public Procurement Law drafted 1.2 Number of strategy and roadmap for building an efficient institutional structure for the new Public Procurement Law developed and adopted 1.3 Number of national public procurement training and professionalisation strategy developed
Indicators for output 2 Output 2.1 • Number of “Refuse To Be Corrupt” cafés established • Number of students’ anti-corruption activities funded by proceeds from “Refuse To Be Corrupt” café
Output 2.2 • Number of “Refuse To Be Corrupt” student clubs are established and active
Output 3 • Number of Integrity and Anti-Corruption Education Centre of Thailand (I-ACT) established
